Description: Scaraboid in glazed composition; back in form of Black African head, with hair represented by squares and facial features crudely cut out; underside decorated with a scorpion with incisions inside its body; pierced lengthwise; no glaze remains; in pink paste; very worn surface.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Musée du Louvre. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Scorpion is a relatively common theme on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the 'Scarab Factory' in Naukratis (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). They were found at Naukratis itself (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 8-10) and in many sites across the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (notably Gorton 1996, 100, type XXVIIIA, subtype A196-203). It was published by Gorton as belonging to her type XXVIII A (no. 203). It would, however, fit better her type XXXIV A, as this scaraboid is made out of coloured paste and the motif is outline with crossed hatched lines on the body of the scorpion (Gorton 1996, 121-123, type XXXIV A). For scorpion motif on scarabs and scaraboids from Naukratis: BM 1886,0401.1606; BM 1886,0401.1607; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.694; Sydney, The Nicholson Museum, University of Sydney NM00.128.7. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 9)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p.100, Type XXVIII A203) (wrong type)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OF.19) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musée du Louvre, Paris
